course.subject: LABU
course.name: Effective Communication in Business
course.description: The course activates students' previously acquired English language skills into a useful managerial communication toolkit targeted toward specific business applications and strategies. Students will learn how to be an effective communicator in the global workplace. The course is designed and structured to address the learning needs of students in job-seeking and in their early careers. Students will have opportunities to learn and practice how to succeed in business writing, presentations, interviews, meetings, and collaborative assignments. The course also introduces students to strategies for handling the communication challenges which fresh graduates can expect in the global workplace. For students who have this course as a program requirement.
course.prerequisites: CORE 1403 OR CORE 1404 OR LANG 1003 (prior to 2022-23)
course.exclusions: LABU 2020 (prior to 2019-20)

reviews.author: vickyman
reviews.comment_content:
There are 3 phases of the course, all aiming to prepare student for job seeking skills or business style of writing and presentation.

Phase I (Weeks 1 ‚Äì 4)
- CV
- Cover Letter
- Digital Portfolio: self-introduction video + CV + cover letter specified for own chosen job ad
- Mock Interview: for own chosen job ad

Phase II (Weeks 5 ‚Äì 9)
- Impromptu Speaking
- Business Writing: for an imaginary startup between a group of 3, 1 student writes the preliminary market analysis, 1 progress report and 1 business plan

Phase III (Weeks 10 ‚Äì 13)
- Business Pitch: for the aforementioned startup, basically a compilation of the above 3 pieces of writing

The contents themselves are useful and applicable in real-life, but frankly speaking you need quite a good solid foundation of English to be able to handle the course well since it heavily demands on English writing and speaking.  Not sure if it's just cause Delian is Canadian or does it apply to other sessions too, the entire course is conducted in English so even if you know the content well in Chinese it wouldn't help much.

The course itself is designed for senior year students as technically it prepares you for working in the society, I would not recommend it for junior year students especially freshmen as you could make better use of this course if you take it in your later years, and that you won't have much to put in your CV or even cover letter, making it difficult to score well in phase I.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Delian is a nice teacher.  Her PowerPoints are easy to refer to when working on assignments and her explanations are very clear.  You will not fall asleep in class as they are packed with content and often requires interaction with her or other students.  

For tasks that require speaking, ie. the mock interview, impromptu speaking and pitching, there were quite many opportunities given for each and everyone of us to practise in class so don't worry too much even if you're not good at public speaking.
reviews.comment_grading:
- 10% Digital Portfolio (including CV, cover letter and self-intro video)
- 10% Mock Interview
- 15% Impromptu Speaking
- 25% Business Writing
- 25% Business Pitch (Team and Individual)
- 5%   Peer Evaluation
- 10% Participation (80% min. attendance)

You get your groupmates assigned for the imaginary startup, there are components in your marks assigned for the coherence of your business writings as well as overall presentation of the business pitch, on top of your individual performance, so Good Luck if your groupmates are hea.
reviews.comment_workload:
Requires quite a lot of writing, schedule a bit tight especially towards end of semester

- Digital Portfolio: CV, 1 page A4 cover letter, 5min self-intro video
- Mock Interview: no preparation outside of class required
- Impromptu Speaking: no preparation outside of class required
- Business Writing: 1500 words
- Business Pitch: 15page PowerPoint + 16min presentation

Worst part is that you have to come up with an "innovative idea" for the imaginary startup in order to proceed with your business writing and pitch, that was quite time consuming.

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.comment_content:
üí¨ Job Interview (Weeks 1 - 4)
Mainly on how to draft your CV, and how to answer commonly asked questions in the interview. It's a 8-min one-to-one interview with your tutor.

üí¨ Impromptu Speech (Weeks 5 - 7)
A 3-min pitch on leadership and teamwork delivered to your colleagues in a social enterprise during a staff retreat.

The setting is weird cuz you have to improvise while standing from an unfamiliar perspective as a colleague in a social enterprise, instead of a student. So talking about your own experience may not work out that well.

üí¨ Pitch Presentation (Weeks 8 - 13)
A 15- to 20-min group presentation (5 min for each group member) on a social innovation idea to a selection panel comprising of your senior management and external investors.

‚úèÔ∏è Business Writing (Weeks 8 - 13)
A 1200- to 1500-word business plan on the social innovation, including market opportunity, market analysis, execution, management, timeline, financial plan, recommendations, basically everything you'd need in a business plan.

I'm still wondering how I could stuff so many sections in merely 1500 words.

But even though with the extra practice rounds I still screwed up. üò≠

reviews.author: Someoneintheuni
reviews.title: Might be helpful if you have 0 job hunting experience
reviews.comment_content:
It's a really functional course which teaches you how to write a CV and cover letter, prepare for an interview, and how to give a public speech in a working environment. Yet since it's a generalization for most of the business jobs and roles, it might not fit each students' career needs perfectly.

The following is from the course syllabus:

Phase I: Effective Communication in Job-Seeking  (Weeks 1 ‚Äì 4)
You will learn how to apply theories and strategies of effective communication to create a positive first impression through compiling your CV and participating in performance-based assessments in a job-seeking context.

Phase II: Effective Communication in Impromptu Speaking (Weeks 5 ‚Äì 8)
You will learn and practice how to communicate with people within an organization through giving impromptu and persuasive presentations.

Phase III: Effective Communication in Pitch Presentation and Business Writing  (Weeks 9 ‚Äì 13)
You will learn and practice how to write to achieve business objectives and communicate persuasively to an internal and external business audience.
reviews.comment_teaching: Due to COVID-19, the class was totally online. It was more like a lecture rather than a tutorial. Even the instructor asks questions sometimes, the class was not delivered in a very interactive way.

Assessed Job Interview (Individual, 20%)
Assessed Impromptu Speech (Individual. 15%)
Assessed Pitch Presentation (Team & Individual, 30%)
Assessed Business Writing (Individual, 30%)
Leadership and Teamwork Evaluation (Individual, 5%)
reviews.comment_workload: Besides the assessment listing in the grading part, there're no additional assignments or take-home tasks. The workload is fine but personally, it just doesn't worth the time since it's not very helpful for my career.

reviews.author: 16y39y
reviews.title: decently useful course
reviews.comment_content:
Phase 1: cv & job interview preparation
Phase 2: impromptu speaking
Phase 3a: business pitch
Phase 3b: business plan

The contents are generally helpful and relevant to BBA students, but nothing very groundbreaking. The course nicely summarizes things that many of us have already learned on our own, from experiences like case comps, job interviews and other courses.

As with any course by CLE, there is a heavier focus on the language aspect than the actual contents (like I felt they were less critical towards the feasibility and creativeness of our ideas), but stricter with the cohesiveness and professionalism of tone.

A lot more practical and useful compared to LABU2040.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Overall, John is a great teacher (don't know why he doesn't have reviews on here, that's specifically why I wrote one). He is a friendly and nice guy who tries hard to make his classes fun and interactive. He has a great energy that would motivate you to listen in his class. He also answers questions after class nicely is quite responsive on email.

His spoken English definitely isn't native, and you can hear some Cantonese accent. But his ability to write in a concise, cohesive and organized manner is very impressive. He once showed us how he rewrote a paragraph from his student's report, which really proved himself to be highly qualified as a LABU teacher.

He does, however, tend to be a bit too creative at times. He likes to encourage us to "think out of the box", and his sample answers to the challenging interview questions are sometimes so creative and unrealistic that HR/recruiters in real life would probably be skeptical of. And quite often he would ever so slightly misinterpret students' answers, but that is not a big issue.

He is a fun man and I had quite a lot of fun in his classes. Also appreciate that he gave quite detailed written feedback for all our assignments.
reviews.comment_grading:
Generally fair grading but not so transparent. Great that they took away the participation score so there is less pressure to participate extensively in classes.

Job Interview (individual) 20%
Impromptu speech (individual) 15%
Business pitch (group) 30%
Business plan (individual) 30%
Peer evaluation 5%

John didn't release most of the scores, and I wasn't able to figure out what grade I got from his feedback either. I think I got around 6/6/6 for the job interview and didn't do so well for the impromptu (his feedback did say that I didn't fulfill many of the requirements). In the end I got A-, which I think is pretty fair (or maybe a bit high) according to how I think I performed.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite light, especially in the beginning. There is no prep required for the impromptu (you could practise some sample questions though, if you wanted). I spent one evening preparing answers to some standard interview questions, and that was it.

The innovation requires a bit more work, and it depends on your groupmates (John let us pick our own groupmates if we wanted to, but seems like none of us knew each other). I had helpful groupmates, we had 3-4 short meetings to discuss the topic and divide our parts. The hard part is making enough content for 20 minutes.

Writing the report is easier since by then you will have all your contents, all you need to do is find some more background information and present it in a nice report. I spent 2 days writing the report.

reviews.author: holam
reviews.title: LABU 2060
reviews.comment_content:
4 parts:
1. Job interview (20%)
Submit a CV (no mark) and submit a job post (no mark)
Then have an 8-min interview
All are general questions. Please well prepare for it.

2. Imprmoptu Speech (15%)
Give you a question (argumentative one) and prepare it in 3-min.  Then make a speech for 3-min. Difficult to prepare, but make sure you fulfil the requirement of your tutor

Rundown: open zoom with your face, receive question , prep 3 min, then your face can disappear for around 4-5 min for shooting a 3 min video, then appear your face again, wait until your tutor receive your video, then leave

3. Group Project
Think of a startup/company for improving the community. You need to use the same thing for the writing and presentation
(a) Writing (30%) (individual)
<1200 writing for your business plan. There are some spcific structure/requirement you need to fulfil. Wrote very clearly in Canvas. Read them.
(b) Group Presentation (20%)+peer evaluation (5%)
15min presentation. This semester is making a zoom recording only. You can NG as many times as you can. But usually the technical problem wastes you lots of time.
This semester does not have Q&A

4. Class participation (10%)
If you are still not able to entertain the tutor when this is the third/fourth Lang class, getting a bad grade is common.

reviews.author: Jerry Wong
reviews.title: Nice course
reviews.comment_content:
The course is divided into 3 phases.

Phase I is job-seeking. You are required to complete digital portfolio (i.e. job ad you chose, your research on the company and your 1-page CV) and an assessed job interview.

Phase II is impromtu speaking and business writing. For impromtu speaking, you will give a 3-minute short speech to the colleagues in a staff retreat. For business writing, you wll be working in a team of 3 on a group project. Each will be responsible for writing one of the three documents. You will negotiate with your team and write the preliminary market analysis, the progress report and the business plan.

Phase III is pitch presentation and peer evaluation. Your team will give a 16+4 minutes' pitch on the group project to an external business audience. Then, you will evaluate your team members' contribution to the group project.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Martha is a patient and a knowledgeable tutor. Before the class, I heard many of my friends saying that she is a "killer". But I don't think so after attending her course.

She gives us many examples on how to promote ourselves during the job interview. She is not only reading her powerpoints, instead, she really keeps on elaborating what she is expecting on. And you can ask for her feedbacks after your practice and assessment, which are useful to your business interview for internship or post-graduate job interview.

For business writing, she shows us examples of writing that fulfils the requirements and also points out the room for improvements. What's more, she also keeps concrete feedbacks on how you can improve, though you may not have chance writing these reports later on :)
reviews.comment_grading:
Phase I: Job-seeking
1. Digital portfolio (5%)
2. Assessed job interview (15%)

Phase II:
1. Impromtu Speaking (15%)
2. Business writing (25%)

Phase III:
1. Pitch presentation (25%)
2. Peer evaluation (5%)

Participation (10%)

I think the grade is fair enough. Even if you are not doing well in phase I, you can still manage to get A range if you work harder and seek more advices from tutor in Phase II and III.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is relatively small to me. It really depends on what other courses are you attending simultaneously. If you are attending other language courses, please do not attend this class in the same semester because you will be going to write numerous writings then. (But if you hate exams, you may try)

Better communication with your teammates facilitate the work. And seeking more advices reduces your time of thinking how to do.

reviews.author: Oscar Wong
reviews.title: Average course
reviews.comment_content: Content is about business communications.  First few weeks focus on CV and interview skills.  Afterwards are impromptu speeches, business reports and pitching.  All topics are business related.  But how effective the trainings are really depends on the tutor.  Labu courses can be really different among various tutors.
reviews.comment_teaching: Martha is a good tutor.  Explanations are clear.  Examples are provided.  Feedback for assignments or in class practice are provided in a timely manner.  I generally receive my grade and feedback for assignments about 1-2 weeks after submission.  If you ask for further advice, Martha will also give you more details on how to improve your English proficiency accordingly.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading.  Everyone is not expecting a very good grade for Labu courses.  I generally score between 3-4 out of 5 in all assignments, perhaps a bit more 3 than 4.  Final grade is B, which is as expected for labu course.
reviews.comment_workload: Labu 2060 has less workload comparing with labu 2040.  For 2060, all you need to do is a demo interview, an impromptu speech, a business report and a pitching presentation.  For the first 2, actually you just need very little time to prepare.  So the main workload will be in the later part of the course, ie when you have to hand in your report and present your ideas.

reviews.comment_teaching:

She mostly introduces the topics using powerpoint then gives us time to practice and discuss.  However, I would say she is rather slow in marking, sometimes, it takes her weeks to return our work.

They tried to cram everything in the last two weels which makes the course a bit stressful towards the end.   However, you cannot blame this on the instructor, it's not her fault.
reviews.comment_grading:
Like all LABU course, it is absolute grading.  So other's performance will not affect your grade.  Every piece of work you hand in will be officially graded and will count towards your final grade.  And each element will weigh differently.

Attendance is important, the minimum attendance requirement for LABU 2060 is 80%. This means that if you are absent for 6 lessons, you will automatically fail the course. Your attendance will be counted starting from the first lesson in the first week. Permission of leave will only be given in special cases of prolonged leave for reasons such as serious illness or injuries on production of documentary evidence.

I will say did put effort in all of the course work but I did not work my butt off so getting a B+ at the end is fair.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is fine as long as you don't leave everything towards the last day.  They do give you enough time to prepare like 2 weeks before deadline.

reviews.comment_content: The course is kind of everywhere and like any other language courses, it's not so much of a content course but a skills course. The classes are taught in small group tutorials style and very much focuses on personal communication skills whether its interview, impromptu presentations, or planned presentations. While these are skills necessary to have in real life, I don't personally see a point in teaching these skills in a dedicated course as it could get extremely tedious and boring.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gloria has been a great teacher considering the level of boringness of this course which I was quite surprised at myself for not falling asleep and this may very well have to to with the instructor's teaching style. She encourage discussions and has tried to make the course as interesting as possible.
While she might not give very clear guidelines as to the final 'startup' project, this is the department's policy and she has  done her best to providing support and clearing up any questions about the project and other assessments.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading was quite fair and like most instructors and professors I found did not skew the grading to make it more or less favorable for the students. As long as the student puts effort into the not so fair workload, the course is unlikely to fail you.
Do keep in mind that attendance is quite important in this course and put the course in the time you think you can stay awake for the longest or simply not skip class. If you miss 10 classes in the course, you will be required to retake the course later on. And your active participation will also leave a good image in the instructors mind which will definitely help in the grading portions for this course because the assessment materials a quite subjective.
reviews.comment_workload:
It hits you when it hits you and if you are a competent speaker and writer in English, there will be no problem in cramming the tasks last minute and still get a super good grade. However, this course doesn't simply hit you once but continuously and could get a tad bit stressful as you go further into the semester.
Last thing, ironing your shirts for the way-too-many formal presentation assessments could be quite some workload.

reviews.title: Bye Bye all LABU
reviews.comment_content: The course is designed and structured to address your learning needs in job-seeking and in your early career. The course introduces students to strategies for handling the communication challenges which fresh graduates can expect in diverse work environments. You will have opportunities to learn and practise how to succeed in business writing, presentations, interviews, meetings, and collaborative assignments with the essential interpersonal communication skills such as active listening, cogent argumentation, and clear expression in writing and speaking.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ms Shen is very nice and kind and friendly. She prepared excellent PPTs for the lectures. There are practice time during lecture (1-2 lectures) for individual interview assessment.

She provided so much time for each group to discuss by their own & raise questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Individual Job Interview 25%
Business Writing 5%
Business Plan 30%
Assessed Business Pitch 30%
Peer evaluation 5%
Learning Portfolio 5%

Eventually B
Interview: 4.5,4.5,4.5
I am not a presentable person, but tried my best. :(
reviews.comment_workload:
Need to prepare the CV, e-portfolio (Google Website)

NOT sure if it would be a good idea if you have never taken any internship (year 1-2) but choose this course for an Interview assessment.
You will be asked to choose a real job advertisement and write your CV matching with the job requirements.

Business Plan Writing is around 2500-2800 words, it is a team writing homework so if you group as 4, each person needs to write 625-700 words, while for 3, around 800-900 words.
You can choose to be an individual writer if you really very not working well with your group, but sad that you can break the group and force everyone (freeriders) to work on individual as well. So you need to hand in one part of your individual Business Plan into your group's Business Plan.

Assessed Business Pitch: can use notecards.
Learning Portfolio: can choose to use Office Sway or Google website

Common sense: as long as you have good group members, your workload will be normal.
I reg this course with my friend but turned out not allowed to choose groupmate. :(

reviews.author: EricKan
reviews.title: Good grade and nice tutor
reviews.comment_content:
The course aims to extend the communication and language skills that you have previously acquired in Labu 2040, and further applies in specific business applications and strategies.
It provides a more job-oriented environment and experience of how a startup starts from 0.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kathy speaks comfortable and fluent English so you won't have problems while attending her lessons.
She doesn't rely on powerpoints very much and gives us to have our own brainstorm session on ideas and projects most of the time.
Quite free in the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Kathy is well known as a good grade tutor.
She is also so kind to her students in class or out of class.
She said that 5 is the mean score in her class so don't worry, it's really good grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
Compared to Labu 2040, the workload of Labu 2060 is extremely light. No more complicated business case analysis, you just have to focus on the presenting and spoken English.
Assignments that we had to do :
1. Prepare the digital portfolio (CV)
2. Job interview (The tutor as an interviewer)
3. Take a stand (3 mins unprepared speech)
4. Business writing (Market analysis, Progress report, Business plan) (Choose 1 out of 3) (1500words)
5. Pitching , the presentation

Attendance should be no big deal.
